{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3606870,"name":"","username":"dejabitz","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/d/edb3f5/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-04-29T03:33:45.862Z","cooked":"

Hi Chief Delphi!

Our team is interested in seeing how we can more quickly debug issues on our CAN bus - esp issues like loose (intermittent) connections or breaks in the wiring. Weâ€™re exploring how to debug this more quickly on the electrical side (as well as improve wiring connection techniques to reduce the chances of these issues), and weâ€™d like to see if we can complement that with software-based diagnostics.

This seems straightforward to do for an entire CAN bus - the roboRIO bus or a CANivore based bus - but not necessarily for individual devices on the bus. We can comb through logs for rx/tx issues, but is it possible to monitor each CAN bus to determine individual device connectivity (in a way thatâ€™s efficient enough to run on the robot during operation), eg rx/tx success/failure or some other connection health metric?

And/or at least for CTRE devices (as a start), would it be better to check on / track something like the StatusSignal from time to time to see if each device is reachable on the appropriate CAN bus?

Thank you!

I donâ€™t think this is what you want butâ€¦

on my test robot, I have a CANable adapter attached to rio CAN bus which attached to a Linux computer. I have a script monitoring roboRIO heartbeat packet. As all device follow FRC CAN specification, I couldn monitor whether each device devices is online or not based on their ID and how many packet I havenâ€™t received. I could also send / monitor roboRIO heartbeat packet to CAN bus (you canâ€™t do the sending part on a real competition robot as this is rule violation)

image926Ã—876 107 KB

Now, more realisticâ€¦ you want to monitor each device on roboRIOâ€¦ You could utilize these API to monitor each device.

https://api.ctr-electronics.com/phoenix6/release/python/autoapi/phoenix6/hardware/index.html?phoenix6.hardware.ParentDevice.is_connected=#phoenix6.hardware.ParentDevice.is_connected

*class* phoenix6.hardware.ParentDevice.is_connected

Before wiring the can bus for the robot our electrical team makes a map of where each device is located and how is it connected in our can bus. Later they use the map to wire the robot.
When we look at a program like phoenix tuner we are able to see which device is missing, and check the map to how it is wired, because we know how it is wired, we know what we should check.
We have done it this way for 3 years now and it didnâ€™t disappoint us
